title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: How to cool down African homes—and keep mosquitoes out
items.description: Painting roofs white and adding screens to doors and windows is a low-cost way to increase comfort and curb malaria risk

items.title: The earliest Homo species did not look human, partial skeleton shows
items.description: Homo habilis, 2 million years old, was known mainly from teeth and jaw bones

items.title: Scientists spot never-before-seen shock wave around dead star
items.description: Observation challenges understanding of how dead stars interact with their environments

items.title: New hepatitis B drug could help ‘functionally cure’ some patients
items.description: Scientists welcome GSK announcement that two trials succeeded—even though data are still lacking

items.title: World’s oldest whale harpoons discovered in Brazil
items.description: Far from the icy Arctic, ancient South Americans hunted whales using whalebone tools

items.title: The Trump administration says some approved childhood vaccines need better studies. Scientists disagree
items.description: Rationale for dropping some vaccine recommendations faces skepticism

items.title: How some people get drunk from their own gut bacteria
items.description: Largest study so far of people with the rare “autobrewery syndrome” points to more culprit microbes

items.title: Ex–Google CEO funds private space telescope bigger than Hubble
items.description: Schmidt Sciences announces investments in orbiting observatory and three ground-based instruments

items.title: Why does Denmark recommend so few childhood vaccines? A Danish scientist explains
items.description: The U.S. plans to follow the Scandinavian country’s minimalist schedule. That may be a mistake, Jens Lundgren says

items.title: Alzheimer’s drug developers accuse clinical trial sites of faking data
items.description: T3D Therapeutics alleges that contract researchers delivered “medically impossible” results on its candidate drug
